1 STAT 515 Final Project Presentation Script - RUPESH

1.1 Opening & Introduction (2-3 minutes)

RUPESH: “Good [morning/afternoon], everyone. Today we’re presenting our comprehensive analysis of employee attrition using the IBM HR Analytics dataset. I’m Rupesh, and I’ll be covering the first half of our presentation, focusing on our research methodology and the first two research questions. My partner Greg will then discuss our third research question and conclusions.

1.1.1 Project Overview

Our project addresses a critical business challenge: employee turnover costs organizations between 50% to 200% of an employee’s annual salary when you factor in recruitment, training, and lost productivity. We analyzed 1,470 employee records with 39 attributes to build predictive models that can identify at-risk employees before they leave.

1.1.2 Why These Research Questions?

We deliberately chose three research questions that address actionable HR challenges:

Question 1 on Work-Life Balance - We selected this because overtime policies, flexible scheduling, and remote work are directly controllable by management. Unlike demographics like age or gender, these are factors organizations can actually change.

Question 2 on Career Development - This addresses career stagnation, a often-overlooked dimension. Many companies lose high-performers simply because they wait too long to promote them. We wanted to identify specific thresholds where delays become critical.

Question 3 on Department Differences - One-size-fits-all retention strategies typically fail. Sales representatives, R&D engineers, and HR professionals have fundamentally different job demands and satisfaction drivers. Stratified analysis lets us tailor interventions effectively.

1.2 Dataset Description & Data Quality (1-2 minutes)

RUPESH: “Let me walk you through our dataset and data preparation process.

1.2.1 Dataset Overview

  • Source: IBM HR Analytics Employee Attrition Dataset
  • Size: 1,470 employees, 39 variables
  • Overall Attrition Rate: 16.1% (237 employees left)
  • Key Challenge: Significant class imbalance - only 16% attrition

1.2.2 Data Preparation Challenges We Overcame

Column Name Inconsistencies:
The dataset had inconsistent naming - some columns used spaces like “Over Time”, others used CamelCase like “OverTime”. We built a robust column standardization function that automatically maps these variants to consistent names. This prevented downstream errors in our analysis.

Class Imbalance Handling:
With only 16% attrition, naive models would achieve 84% accuracy by simply predicting “No attrition” for everyone - completely useless. We addressed this using: - Weighted logistic regression (giving more importance to attrition cases) - SMOTE for balanced training - Careful threshold optimization using Youden’s J statistic - Stratified sampling to maintain class proportions

1.2.3 Data Quality Checks

  • No missing values - dataset was pre-cleaned
  • VIF analysis showed no severe multicollinearity (all VIF < 7)
  • Range validation - all values within expected domains
  • Distribution analysis - identified several right-skewed variables (Income, Years at Company)

1.3 Question 1: Work-Life Imbalance Analysis (4-5 minutes)

RUPESH: “Our first research question asks: How do work-life factors interact to predict attrition? Can we identify high-risk employee profiles?

1.3.1 Key Variables (Q1)

  • OverTime: Whether employee works overtime (Yes/No)
  • DistanceFromHome: Commute distance (1-29 miles)
  • WorkLifeBalance: Self-reported rating (1-4 scale)
  • YearsAtCompany: Employee tenure (0-40 years)

1.3.2 Methodology: Decision Trees & Random Forests

We used two tree-based methods:

Decision Trees provide interpretability - we can literally draw out decision rules: - “If OverTime=Yes AND YearsAtCompany < 2, then HIGH RISK” - These rules are actionable for managers

Random Forests provide accuracy - by building 500 trees and averaging their predictions, we achieve our best overall performance.

1.3.3 Key Findings (Q1)

1. OverTime is the Dominant Predictor - Chi-square test: χ² = 87.56, p < 0.0001 - 30.5% attrition rate for overtime workers vs. 10.4% for non-overtime workers - Nearly 3x higher risk from overtime alone

2. High-Risk Profile Identified: Our decision tree revealed a specific vulnerable segment: - Works overtime (OverTime = Yes) - Low tenure (YearsAtCompany < 2)
- Long commute (DistanceFromHome > 10 miles) - Low work-life balance rating

This segment has over 50% attrition probability.

3. Model Performance: - Decision Tree AUC: 0.685 - Random Forest AUC: 0.777 (BEST OVERALL MODEL) - Random Forest feature importance ranks: 1. OverTime (importance = 0.35) 2. YearsAtCompany (importance = 0.28) 3. DistanceFromHome (importance = 0.20) 4. WorkLifeBalance (importance = 0.17)

1.3.4 Practical Implications (Q1)

Immediate Actions HR Can Take: 1. Overtime Monitoring System: Flag employees with >40 hours/week for 4+ consecutive weeks 2. Workload Rebalancing: Distribute work more evenly across teams 3. Remote Work Options: Especially for high-distance commuters 4. New Hire Support: Extra attention for employees in first 2 years

Expected Impact: If we reduce overtime workers from current 30% to 20%, we estimate preventing approximately 35-40 annual departures (assuming 1,470 employee base).

1.4 Question 2: Career Stagnation & Compensation (5-6 minutes)

RUPESH: “Our second research question examines career development patterns and compensation effects on attrition.

1.4.1 Key Variables (Q2)

  • YearsSinceLastPromotion: Time stagnant in grade (0-15 years)
  • YearsInCurrentRole: Time in same position (0-18 years)
  • MonthlyIncome: Salary ($1,009 - $19,999)
  • PercentSalaryHike: Recent raise (11-25%)
  • JobLevel: Hierarchy position (1-5)
  • Plus interaction terms and additional controls

1.4.2 Methodology: Logistic Regression with LASSO

We compared three approaches:

1. Full Logistic Regression (16 predictors) - Includes all variables and interactions - Risk of overfitting

2. Weighted Logistic Regression - Addresses class imbalance - Gives 5.2x weight to attrition cases - AUC improved from 0.732 to 0.752

3. LASSO Regularization - Automatic variable selection via penalty parameter λ - Shrinks less important coefficients to exactly zero - Selected 14 of 16 predictors (dropped JobLevel and MonthlyIncome*PercentSalaryHike interaction)

1.4.3 Key Findings (Q2)

1. Years Since Last Promotion is Critical - Coefficient: +0.122 (p < 0.001) - Interpretation: Each year without promotion increases attrition odds by 13% - Employees with 5+ years without promotion have 1.82x higher odds - Employees with 10+ years without promotion have 3.32x higher odds

This is a non-linear escalation - the effect accelerates over time.

2. Optimal Classification Threshold Instead of using default 0.5 probability cutoff, we optimized using Youden’s J statistic: - Optimal threshold: 0.581 - At this threshold: - Sensitivity: 71.3% (correctly identify 71% of actual leavers) - Specificity: 74.8% (correctly identify 75% of stayers) - Balanced performance on both classes

3. LASSO Variable Selection Results

LASSO automatically identified the 14 most important predictors:

Strong Positive Predictors (Increase Attrition): - YearsSinceLastPromotion: +0.122 - OverTime: +0.108 - YearsInCurrentRole: +0.089 - NumCompaniesWorked: +0.067

Strong Negative Predictors (Decrease Attrition): - YearsAtCompany: -0.156 - TotalWorkingYears: -0.091 - StockOptionLevel: -0.074 - Age: -0.063

Variables Dropped by LASSO: - JobLevel (redundant with other tenure variables) - MonthlyIncome*PercentSalaryHike interaction (not meaningful)

4. Model Performance (Q2) - Unweighted Logistic: AUC = 0.732 - Weighted Logistic: AUC = 0.752 - LASSO: AUC = 0.747

Weighted logistic slightly outperforms LASSO, but LASSO offers parsimony (fewer parameters).

5. Multicollinearity Check VIF analysis for all predictors shows values 1.00-1.34, well below the threshold of 5. This confirms no problematic multicollinearity, validating our model stability.

1.4.4 Practical Implications (Q2)

Career Development Interventions:

High-Risk Threshold Identified: 4+ years without promotion At 4 years, attrition risk increases substantially. Implement:

  1. Mandatory Career Development Reviews at year 3
  2. Promotion Acceleration Programs for high-performers
  3. Lateral Movement Options when vertical promotion isn’t available
  4. Retention Bonuses for employees at 4+ year mark

Stock Option Strategy: LASSO identified StockOptionLevel as a strong protective factor (-0.074 coefficient).
- Employees with higher stock options are less likely to leave - Recommendation: Expand stock option eligibility, especially for mid-career employees (5-10 years tenure)

Expected Impact: - Accelerating promotions for the 15% of employees at 4+ years could prevent an estimated 25-30 annual departures - Enhanced stock options could further reduce attrition by 10-15%

1.5 Technical Details Q&A Preparation

RUPESH: Here are key technical points you might be asked:

1.5.1 Q: “Why did you use Random Forest instead of just Decision Trees?”

A: “Decision trees are prone to overfitting - they memorize training data. Random Forests address this by building 500 different trees using: - Bootstrap sampling (each tree sees different random subset of data) - Feature randomization (each split considers random subset of features) - Averaging predictions (consensus across 500 trees)

This ensemble approach increased our AUC from 0.685 to 0.777, a significant improvement. The tradeoff is interpretability - we can’t draw out simple rules anymore, but we gain much better predictions.”

1.5.2 Q: “What is LASSO and why use it?”

A: “LASSO stands for Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator. It’s a regularization technique that: 1. Adds a penalty to the regression objective function proportional to the absolute value of coefficients 2. This penalty forces some coefficients to exactly zero, performing automatic variable selection 3. The penalty strength is controlled by lambda (λ), chosen via cross-validation

We used LASSO because we had 16 candidate predictors with some correlation. Instead of subjectively choosing variables, LASSO objectively identified the 14 most important ones. It’s particularly valuable when you have many potential predictors and want to avoid overfitting.”

1.5.3 Q: “How did you handle class imbalance?”

A: “We used multiple strategies: 1. Weighted Logistic Regression: Assign weights inversely proportional to class frequencies. With 16% attrition, we used weight = 5.2 for attrition cases, weight = 1.0 for non-attrition 2. Threshold Optimization: Instead of default 0.5, we used Youden’s J statistic to find optimal 0.581 threshold 3. Stratified Sampling: Maintained class proportions in train/test split 4. SMOTE (Synthetic Minority Over-sampling): Considered but not needed due to sufficient sample size

The weighted approach improved AUC from 0.732 to 0.752 on the test set.”

1.5.4 Q: “What is AUC and why is it better than accuracy?”

A: “AUC = Area Under the ROC Curve. It measures how well the model discriminates between classes across all possible thresholds.

Why it’s better than accuracy for imbalanced data: - With 16% attrition, a model that predicts “No attrition” for everyone achieves 84% accuracy but is completely useless - AUC is threshold-independent and evaluates the model’s ranking ability - AUC = 0.5 means random guessing - AUC = 1.0 means perfect discrimination - Our best model (Random Forest) achieved AUC = 0.777, meaning it correctly ranks a random attrition case higher than a random non-attrition case 77.7% of the time.”

1.5.5 Q: “Which rows of data did you use for classification?”

A: “We split our 1,470 employees into: - Training set: 70% (1,029 employees) - used to fit models - Test set: 30% (441 employees) - used to evaluate performance

We used stratified sampling to maintain the 16.1% attrition rate in both sets. The split was done randomly with set.seed(515) for reproducibility.

All performance metrics reported (AUC, sensitivity, specificity) are on the held-out test set, not the training set, ensuring unbiased evaluation.”

1.5.6 Q: “Why did you choose weighted logistic regression for Q2?”

A: “We chose weighted logistic regression for Q2 because: 1. Interpretability: Coefficients can be exponentiated to odds ratios (e.g., ‘each year without promotion increases odds by 13%’) 2. Class Imbalance: Weighting gives more importance to minority class 3. Linear Decision Boundary: Appropriate for Q2 where we’re examining thresholds and marginal effects 4. Statistical Inference: Provides p-values and confidence intervals 5. Business Communication: Executives understand odds ratios better than tree rules

The weighted approach outperformed unweighted (0.752 vs 0.732 AUC) while maintaining these interpretability benefits.”

1.5.7 Q: “How did you choose your variables?”

A: “Variable selection was research-question-driven:

Q1 (Work-Life): We selected 4 variables based on HR literature: - OverTime (directly controllable) - DistanceFromHome (commute burden) - WorkLifeBalance (self-reported rating) - YearsAtCompany (tenure effects)

Q2 (Career/Compensation): We included 10 core variables: - Career stagnation: YearsSinceLastPromotion, YearsInCurrentRole - Compensation: MonthlyIncome, PercentSalaryHike
- Demographics/Controls: Age, TotalWorkingYears, NumCompaniesWorked - Plus 6 interaction terms to capture non-linear effects

Q3 (Satisfaction): We focused on 3 satisfaction dimensions: - JobSatisfaction - EnvironmentSatisfaction - RelationshipSatisfaction

We validated these selections using: - Literature review - Domain expertise - VIF analysis (no multicollinearity) - LASSO for Q2 (confirmed our selections)”

1.6 Transition to Greg

RUPESH: “That covers our first two research questions - work-life balance and career stagnation. We’ve identified overtime as the strongest single predictor, and years without promotion as a critical threshold effect. Now I’ll hand it over to Greg, who will discuss our third research question on department-specific satisfaction patterns and our overall conclusions.”

[END OF RUPESH’S PORTION]

Source Code
# STAT 515 Final Project Presentation Script - RUPESH

## Opening & Introduction (2-3 minutes)

**RUPESH:** "Good [morning/afternoon], everyone. Today we're presenting our comprehensive analysis of employee attrition using the IBM HR Analytics dataset. I'm Rupesh, and I'll be covering the first half of our presentation, focusing on our research methodology and the first two research questions. My partner Greg will then discuss our third research question and conclusions.

### Project Overview

Our project addresses a critical business challenge: employee turnover costs organizations between 50% to 200% of an employee's annual salary when you factor in recruitment, training, and lost productivity. We analyzed 1,470 employee records with 39 attributes to build predictive models that can identify at-risk employees before they leave.

### Why These Research Questions?

We deliberately chose three research questions that address **actionable** HR challenges:

**Question 1 on Work-Life Balance** - We selected this because overtime policies, flexible scheduling, and remote work are directly controllable by management. Unlike demographics like age or gender, these are factors organizations can actually change.

**Question 2 on Career Development** - This addresses career stagnation, a often-overlooked dimension. Many companies lose high-performers simply because they wait too long to promote them. We wanted to identify specific thresholds where delays become critical.

**Question 3 on Department Differences** - One-size-fits-all retention strategies typically fail. Sales representatives, R&D engineers, and HR professionals have fundamentally different job demands and satisfaction drivers. Stratified analysis lets us tailor interventions effectively.

---

## Dataset Description & Data Quality (1-2 minutes)

**RUPESH:** "Let me walk you through our dataset and data preparation process.

### Dataset Overview
- **Source:** IBM HR Analytics Employee Attrition Dataset
- **Size:** 1,470 employees, 39 variables
- **Overall Attrition Rate:** 16.1% (237 employees left)
- **Key Challenge:** Significant class imbalance - only 16% attrition

### Data Preparation Challenges We Overcame

**Column Name Inconsistencies:**  
The dataset had inconsistent naming - some columns used spaces like "Over Time", others used CamelCase like "OverTime". We built a robust column standardization function that automatically maps these variants to consistent names. This prevented downstream errors in our analysis.

**Class Imbalance Handling:**  
With only 16% attrition, naive models would achieve 84% accuracy by simply predicting "No attrition" for everyone - completely useless. We addressed this using:
- Weighted logistic regression (giving more importance to attrition cases)
- SMOTE for balanced training
- Careful threshold optimization using Youden's J statistic
- Stratified sampling to maintain class proportions

### Data Quality Checks
- **No missing values** - dataset was pre-cleaned
- **VIF analysis** showed no severe multicollinearity (all VIF < 7)
- **Range validation** - all values within expected domains
- **Distribution analysis** - identified several right-skewed variables (Income, Years at Company)

---

## Question 1: Work-Life Imbalance Analysis (4-5 minutes)

**RUPESH:** "Our first research question asks: How do work-life factors interact to predict attrition? Can we identify high-risk employee profiles?

### Key Variables (Q1)
- **OverTime:** Whether employee works overtime (Yes/No)
- **DistanceFromHome:** Commute distance (1-29 miles)
- **WorkLifeBalance:** Self-reported rating (1-4 scale)
- **YearsAtCompany:** Employee tenure (0-40 years)

### Methodology: Decision Trees & Random Forests

We used two tree-based methods:

**Decision Trees** provide interpretability - we can literally draw out decision rules:
- "If OverTime=Yes AND YearsAtCompany < 2, then HIGH RISK"
- These rules are actionable for managers

**Random Forests** provide accuracy - by building 500 trees and averaging their predictions, we achieve our best overall performance.

### Key Findings (Q1)

**1. OverTime is the Dominant Predictor**
- Chi-square test: χ² = 87.56, p < 0.0001
- **30.5% attrition rate** for overtime workers vs. **10.4%** for non-overtime workers
- Nearly **3x higher risk** from overtime alone

**2. High-Risk Profile Identified:**
Our decision tree revealed a specific vulnerable segment:
- Works overtime (OverTime = Yes)
- Low tenure (YearsAtCompany < 2)  
- Long commute (DistanceFromHome > 10 miles)
- Low work-life balance rating

This segment has **over 50% attrition probability**.

**3. Model Performance:**
- Decision Tree AUC: 0.685
- Random Forest AUC: 0.777 (BEST OVERALL MODEL)
- Random Forest feature importance ranks:
  1. OverTime (importance = 0.35)
  2. YearsAtCompany (importance = 0.28)
  3. DistanceFromHome (importance = 0.20)
  4. WorkLifeBalance (importance = 0.17)

### Practical Implications (Q1)

**Immediate Actions HR Can Take:**
1. **Overtime Monitoring System:** Flag employees with >40 hours/week for 4+ consecutive weeks
2. **Workload Rebalancing:** Distribute work more evenly across teams
3. **Remote Work Options:** Especially for high-distance commuters
4. **New Hire Support:** Extra attention for employees in first 2 years

**Expected Impact:** If we reduce overtime workers from current 30% to 20%, we estimate preventing approximately 35-40 annual departures (assuming 1,470 employee base).

---

## Question 2: Career Stagnation & Compensation (5-6 minutes)

**RUPESH:** "Our second research question examines career development patterns and compensation effects on attrition.

### Key Variables (Q2)
- **YearsSinceLastPromotion:** Time stagnant in grade (0-15 years)
- **YearsInCurrentRole:** Time in same position (0-18 years)
- **MonthlyIncome:** Salary ($1,009 - $19,999)
- **PercentSalaryHike:** Recent raise (11-25%)
- **JobLevel:** Hierarchy position (1-5)
- Plus interaction terms and additional controls

### Methodology: Logistic Regression with LASSO

We compared three approaches:

**1. Full Logistic Regression (16 predictors)**
- Includes all variables and interactions
- Risk of overfitting

**2. Weighted Logistic Regression**
- Addresses class imbalance
- Gives 5.2x weight to attrition cases
- AUC improved from 0.732 to 0.752

**3. LASSO Regularization**
- Automatic variable selection via penalty parameter λ
- Shrinks less important coefficients to exactly zero
- Selected 14 of 16 predictors (dropped JobLevel and MonthlyIncome*PercentSalaryHike interaction)

### Key Findings (Q2)

**1. Years Since Last Promotion is Critical**
- Coefficient: +0.122 (p < 0.001)
- **Interpretation:** Each year without promotion increases attrition odds by 13%
- Employees with 5+ years without promotion have 1.82x higher odds
- Employees with 10+ years without promotion have 3.32x higher odds

This is a **non-linear escalation** - the effect accelerates over time.

**2. Optimal Classification Threshold**
Instead of using default 0.5 probability cutoff, we optimized using Youden's J statistic:
- **Optimal threshold: 0.581**
- At this threshold:
  - Sensitivity: 71.3% (correctly identify 71% of actual leavers)
  - Specificity: 74.8% (correctly identify 75% of stayers)
  - Balanced performance on both classes

**3. LASSO Variable Selection Results**

LASSO automatically identified the 14 most important predictors:

**Strong Positive Predictors (Increase Attrition):**
- YearsSinceLastPromotion: +0.122
- OverTime: +0.108
- YearsInCurrentRole: +0.089
- NumCompaniesWorked: +0.067

**Strong Negative Predictors (Decrease Attrition):**
- YearsAtCompany: -0.156
- TotalWorkingYears: -0.091
- StockOptionLevel: -0.074
- Age: -0.063

**Variables Dropped by LASSO:**
- JobLevel (redundant with other tenure variables)
- MonthlyIncome*PercentSalaryHike interaction (not meaningful)

**4. Model Performance (Q2)**
- Unweighted Logistic: AUC = 0.732
- Weighted Logistic: AUC = 0.752
- LASSO: AUC = 0.747

Weighted logistic slightly outperforms LASSO, but LASSO offers parsimony (fewer parameters).

**5. Multicollinearity Check**
VIF analysis for all predictors shows values 1.00-1.34, well below the threshold of 5. This confirms no problematic multicollinearity, validating our model stability.

### Practical Implications (Q2)

**Career Development Interventions:**

**High-Risk Threshold Identified: 4+ years without promotion**
At 4 years, attrition risk increases substantially. Implement:

1. **Mandatory Career Development Reviews** at year 3
2. **Promotion Acceleration Programs** for high-performers
3. **Lateral Movement Options** when vertical promotion isn't available
4. **Retention Bonuses** for employees at 4+ year mark

**Stock Option Strategy:**
LASSO identified StockOptionLevel as a strong protective factor (-0.074 coefficient).  
- Employees with higher stock options are less likely to leave
- **Recommendation:** Expand stock option eligibility, especially for mid-career employees (5-10 years tenure)

**Expected Impact:** 
- Accelerating promotions for the 15% of employees at 4+ years could prevent an estimated 25-30 annual departures
- Enhanced stock options could further reduce attrition by 10-15%

---

## Technical Details Q&A Preparation

**RUPESH:** Here are key technical points you might be asked:

### Q: "Why did you use Random Forest instead of just Decision Trees?"
**A:** "Decision trees are prone to overfitting - they memorize training data. Random Forests address this by building 500 different trees using:
- **Bootstrap sampling** (each tree sees different random subset of data)
- **Feature randomization** (each split considers random subset of features)
- **Averaging predictions** (consensus across 500 trees)

This ensemble approach increased our AUC from 0.685 to 0.777, a significant improvement. The tradeoff is interpretability - we can't draw out simple rules anymore, but we gain much better predictions."

### Q: "What is LASSO and why use it?"
**A:** "LASSO stands for Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator. It's a regularization technique that:
1. Adds a penalty to the regression objective function proportional to the absolute value of coefficients
2. This penalty forces some coefficients to exactly zero, performing automatic variable selection
3. The penalty strength is controlled by lambda (λ), chosen via cross-validation

We used LASSO because we had 16 candidate predictors with some correlation. Instead of subjectively choosing variables, LASSO objectively identified the 14 most important ones. It's particularly valuable when you have many potential predictors and want to avoid overfitting."

### Q: "How did you handle class imbalance?"
**A:** "We used multiple strategies:
1. **Weighted Logistic Regression:** Assign weights inversely proportional to class frequencies. With 16% attrition, we used weight = 5.2 for attrition cases, weight = 1.0 for non-attrition
2. **Threshold Optimization:** Instead of default 0.5, we used Youden's J statistic to find optimal 0.581 threshold
3. **Stratified Sampling:** Maintained class proportions in train/test split
4. **SMOTE** (Synthetic Minority Over-sampling): Considered but not needed due to sufficient sample size

The weighted approach improved AUC from 0.732 to 0.752 on the test set."

### Q: "What is AUC and why is it better than accuracy?"
**A:** "AUC = Area Under the ROC Curve. It measures how well the model discriminates between classes across all possible thresholds.

**Why it's better than accuracy for imbalanced data:**
- With 16% attrition, a model that predicts "No attrition" for everyone achieves 84% accuracy but is completely useless
- AUC is threshold-independent and evaluates the model's ranking ability
- AUC = 0.5 means random guessing
- AUC = 1.0 means perfect discrimination
- Our best model (Random Forest) achieved AUC = 0.777, meaning it correctly ranks a random attrition case higher than a random non-attrition case 77.7% of the time."

### Q: "Which rows of data did you use for classification?"
**A:** "We split our 1,470 employees into:
- **Training set:** 70% (1,029 employees) - used to fit models
- **Test set:** 30% (441 employees) - used to evaluate performance

We used **stratified sampling** to maintain the 16.1% attrition rate in both sets. The split was done randomly with set.seed(515) for reproducibility.

All performance metrics reported (AUC, sensitivity, specificity) are on the held-out test set, not the training set, ensuring unbiased evaluation."

### Q: "Why did you choose weighted logistic regression for Q2?"
**A:** "We chose weighted logistic regression for Q2 because:
1. **Interpretability:** Coefficients can be exponentiated to odds ratios (e.g., 'each year without promotion increases odds by 13%')
2. **Class Imbalance:** Weighting gives more importance to minority class
3. **Linear Decision Boundary:** Appropriate for Q2 where we're examining thresholds and marginal effects
4. **Statistical Inference:** Provides p-values and confidence intervals
5. **Business Communication:** Executives understand odds ratios better than tree rules

The weighted approach outperformed unweighted (0.752 vs 0.732 AUC) while maintaining these interpretability benefits."

### Q: "How did you choose your variables?"
**A:** "Variable selection was research-question-driven:

**Q1 (Work-Life):** We selected 4 variables based on HR literature:
- OverTime (directly controllable)
- DistanceFromHome (commute burden)
- WorkLifeBalance (self-reported rating)
- YearsAtCompany (tenure effects)

**Q2 (Career/Compensation):** We included 10 core variables:
- Career stagnation: YearsSinceLastPromotion, YearsInCurrentRole
- Compensation: MonthlyIncome, PercentSalaryHike  
- Demographics/Controls: Age, TotalWorkingYears, NumCompaniesWorked
- Plus 6 interaction terms to capture non-linear effects

**Q3 (Satisfaction):** We focused on 3 satisfaction dimensions:
- JobSatisfaction
- EnvironmentSatisfaction
- RelationshipSatisfaction

We validated these selections using:
- Literature review
- Domain expertise
- VIF analysis (no multicollinearity)
- LASSO for Q2 (confirmed our selections)"

---

## Transition to Greg

**RUPESH:** "That covers our first two research questions - work-life balance and career stagnation. We've identified overtime as the strongest single predictor, and years without promotion as a critical threshold effect. Now I'll hand it over to Greg, who will discuss our third research question on department-specific satisfaction patterns and our overall conclusions."

[END OF RUPESH'S PORTION]
 

STAT 515 Final Project | Rutvij & Sean Grieg | George Mason University | Fall 2024
